awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Cyber Security Research at Wright State University
awd_abstract_narration:
This CISE Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site award funds a new REU site focuses on cybersecurity at Wright State University. Each summer, students will work with experienced faculty mentors state-of-the-art facilities and emerging tools and techniques to solve problems that are timely and important.   The challenges of cybersecurity research provide an exciting opportunity for students to investigate fundamental principles and strategies to develop real-world, secure systems that we can all trust. This project is co-funded by the Cyber Corps (R): Scholarship for Service Program.

The project is led by an outstanding team offering modern facilities and professional mentors to guide undergraduates in explorations of problems related to cybersecurity.  The team will use proven strategies to recruit undergraduate students from groups traditionally under-represented in computer science. The team will also seek to include veterans who are returning to pursue computing degrees   The students will participate in research and professional development activities all designed to achieve the goals of retaining and graduating undergraduate students in computer fields, recruiting students from groups traditionally under-represented in computing fields,  developing students' confidence and capabilities of conducting independent research, and motivating students to pursue graduate programs.

por.por_cntn:
The severity of cyber threats implies an acute demand of security professionals capable of designing effective solutions. This entails the higher education system’s engagement to train and nurture students capable of developing both principles and techniques to meet this demand. To this end, we have built an REU site in Cyber Security Research at Wright State University (WSU). Our REU site has accomplished four goals. First, we have recruited a diverse group of 31 motivated undergraduate students to participate in our REU site, who are mainly from institutions with limited cyber security research programs. Second, we have developed students’ confidence and capabilities of conducting independent research. Third, our program has encouraged students for graduate studies. Finally, it has motivated students to develop their career interest in cyber security.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual focus of the proposed REU site consists of four complementary components: security and data analytics techniques, problem-solving methodologies, academic communication skills, and professional development. First, students have acquired in-depth knowledge of cyber security and sharpened their analytic skills by analyzing various real-world attacking and defending examples. Second, students have learnt, wherever applicable, through the “end-to-end” approach, the entire process of problem-solving methodologies. Third, our REU site implemented various faculty-student and student-student interactions to promote the dialogues between faculty mentors and students, and dialogues among students, thereby generating academic interaction and discussions that extend beyond research. Finally, students’ professional development will be enhanced by interacting with speakers from industry. Research projects supported by this site has also resulted in various innovative security systems such as a system to detect HTTP-based information exfiltration of malicious android application and a system to detect PHP-based malicious web shells.

Broader Impacts This REU site has provided research experiences in cyber security to a diverse group of motivated undergraduate students from institutions whose cyber security research is very limited or does not exist. It has resulted in improved education and research experience for students and improved professional development/employment in research fields. Wright State University has leveraged this site to enhance its existing partnership with regional universities and develop new collaboration with other Ohio and national universities. It has fostered cooperative cyber security research that benefits undergraduate students. Technical research results from this research were published in several major journals and conferences in cyber security, such as Computers & Security, IEEE International Conference On Trust, Security And Privacy In Computing And Communications, and AAAI Fall Symposium on Privacy and Language Technologies.
